content: The Act may be cited as the "West Nile Virus and Arboviral Disease Act" and includes a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases. Section 319 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a temporary program for West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases, allowing the Secretary to make grants to States for prevention and control efforts. The Secretary can make grants to States for the prevention and control of West Nile Virus and related arboviral diseases, with a preference for states with a higher incidence or prevalence of these diseases. States are encouraged to collaborate with local health entities for program development. The Secretary can award grants to States for prevention and control programs related to West Nile Virus and arboviral diseases. Preference may be given to States with a substantial incidence or prevalence of these diseases or increased risk. Grant funds must be used for specified purposes. The grant funds awarded to States for prevention and control programs related to West Nile Virus and arboviral diseases must be used for developing and implementing community-based mosquito control plans and programs on medical entomology and arbovirology. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section for an Arbovirus Research Program. The President is mandated to enhance research to control insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus, develop rapid screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies. The President is required to enhance research to control insect populations transmitting diseases like West Nile Virus, develop rapid screening tools, pathogen inactivation technologies, and containment methodologies. Activities may include examining and developing new methodologies for controlling insect populations. Activities under subsection (a) may involve examining and developing methodologies to control insect populations for the spread of the West Nile Virus and related arboviruses. Entities involved in these activities may include the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, other Institutes at the National Institutes of Health, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the Food and Drug Administration, among other relevant Federal Government entities. The President shall promote coordination between relevant Federal agencies, private sector, and individuals with expertise in public health, entomology, arbovirology, and veterinary health.
